title: 103_s277
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National African American Museum Act". The Congress finds that the presentation and preservation of African American life, art, history, and culture within the National Park System and other Federal entities is inadequate, restricting understanding of African American experiences and struggles. Public Law 99-511 encouraged support for a commemorative structure within the National Park System or on other Federal lands. The establishment of a national museum dedicated to African American heritage and culture within the National Park System or on Federal lands is crucial for promoting understanding and education about the contributions of African Americans to society. The current lack of a national institution solely focused on African American life, art, history, or culture within the Smithsonian Institution highlights the need for such a museum. Establishment of the National African American Museum. The National African American Museum is established within the Smithsonian Institution with the purpose of serving as a center for scholarship, hosting exhibits, collecting artifacts, providing education programs, and training museum professionals in African American life, art, history, and culture. The Board of Regents is authorized to plan, design, reconstruct, and renovate the Arts and Industries building of the Smithsonian Institution to house the National African American Museum. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum is established within the Smithsonian Institution, composed of 23 members appointed by various officials including the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution and members of Congress. The Board of Regents of the National African American Museum is composed of 23 members appointed by various officials, including the Majority Leader of the Senate, the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, the Congressional Black Caucus, and the African American Museum Association. Initial appointments are made by the Board of Regents. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum is appointed by the Board of Regents and nominations from the African American Institutional Study Advisory Committee of the Smithsonian Institution. Members serve 3-year terms and may be reappointed, with staggered terms for initial appointees. The terms of Board of Trustees members appointed under specific subsections expire after 2 or 3 years. Vacancies do not affect the Board's powers and are filled as per original appointment. Members serve without pay but receive expenses. The Board of Trustees members receive per diem, travel, and transportation expenses. The chairperson is elected by a majority vote. Meetings are called by the chairperson or upon request of a majority of members, at least twice a year. A majority constitutes a quorum for conducting business. The chairperson of the Board of Trustees may accept voluntary services from a member of the Board, despite certain restrictions. The Board of Trustees of the Museum has duties outlined in Section 6. The Board of Trustees of the Museum has the authority to recommend budgets, manage collections, and acquire artifacts for the Museum. The Museum's Board of Trustees establishes policies for collection utilization, programming, education, exhibitions, and research related to African American life and culture. They also have authority to provide restoration, solicit funds, and approve expenditures from the endowment. The Museum's Board of Trustees has the authority to approve expenditures from the endowment for any purpose of the Museum and to support the Director in its operation. They also establish programs in collaboration with other African American museums and organizations to promote understanding of African American life, art, history, and culture. The Museum's Board of Trustees is responsible for developing cooperative programs and exhibitions, managing collections, training museum professionals, and creating research fellowships and internships. They must adopt bylaws and report annually to the Board of Regents on the acquisition and display of African American objects and artifacts. The Museum's Board of Trustees is responsible for developing programs, managing collections, and creating research opportunities. SEC. 7 states the Director and Staff. The Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution appoints key museum staff, including the Director, Assistant Director, Secretary, and Chief Curator, without following certain civil service laws. The appointed individuals must be qualified for their roles. The Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution appoints key museum staff without following certain civil service laws related to classification and pay rates. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS.

(1) "Board of Regents" refers to the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution.
(2) "Board of Trustees" refers to the Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum.
(3) "Museum" refers to the National African American Museum.
(4) "Arts and Industries building" refers to the building located on the Mall at 900 Jefferson Drive, S.W. in Washington, D.C.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for succeeding years as needed.
